annotation.spannedText: health officials suspected the outbreak may have been linked to pockets of people who refuse vaccinations

classMention.mentionClass: health officials suspected the outbreak may have been linked to pockets of people who refuse vaccinations

annotation.spannedText: In order for a population to achieve “herd immunity,” which means it’s considered to be well-protected against measles, more than 95 percent of people need to receive the MMR vaccine that prevents them from contracting the infectious disease

classMention.mentionClass: In order for a population to achieve “herd immunity,” which means it’s considered to be well-protected against measles, more than 95 percent of people need to receive the MMR vaccine that prevents them from contracting the infectious disease

annotation.spannedText: the people who were infected in the recent measles outbreak have vaccination rates that fall well below that recommended threshold

classMention.mentionClass: the people who were infected in the recent measles outbreak have vaccination rates that fall well below that recommended threshold

annotation.spannedText: new research published in JAMA Pediatrics

classMention.mentionClass: new research published in JAMA Pediatrics

annotation.spannedText: Clearly, MMR vaccination rates in many of the communities that have been affected by this outbreak fall well below the necessary threshold to sustain herd immunity, thus placing the greater population at risk as well

classMention.mentionClass: Clearly, MMR vaccination rates in many of the communities that have been affected by this outbreak fall well below the necessary threshold to sustain herd immunity, thus placing the greater population at risk as well

annotation.spannedText: measles was able to spread quickly among clusters of families who have rejected the government’s immunization schedule for their children

classMention.mentionClass: measles was able to spread quickly among clusters of families who have rejected the government’s immunization schedule for their children

annotation.spannedText: The Disneyland outbreak is quite possibly a direct consequence of the growing anti-vaccination movement in the United States

classMention.mentionClass: The Disneyland outbreak is quite possibly a direct consequence of the growing anti-vaccination movement in the United States

annotation.spannedText: if that movement continues to grow, “the likelihood of outbreaks will increase — as will their scale and scope

classMention.mentionClass: if that movement continues to grow, “the likelihood of outbreaks will increase — as will their scale and scope

annotation.spannedText: while experts have speculated that the recent spread of measles was due to low vaccine rates, her study “confirms this suspicion in a scientifically rigorous way

classMention.mentionClass: while experts have speculated that the recent spread of measles was due to low vaccine rates, her study “confirms this suspicion in a scientifically rigorous way

annotation.spannedText: federal health officials have tracked a rise in the number of measles cases that they say are driven by a fewer number of people getting the MMR shot

classMention.mentionClass: federal health officials have tracked a rise in the number of measles cases that they say are driven by a fewer number of people getting the MMR shot

annotation.spannedText: A large portion of vaccine skeptical parents are opting to delay vaccines, spacing out their kids’ shots based on the misguided belief that it’s harmful for children to get too many shots at once

classMention.mentionClass: A large portion of vaccine skeptical parents are opting to delay vaccines, spacing out their kids’ shots based on the misguided belief that it’s harmful for children to get too many shots at once

annotation.spannedText: That can leave their children unprotected for longer than they would have been otherwise — potentially exposing them to diseases like measles, even if their parents are planning on eventually giving them the MMR shot.

classMention.mentionClass: That can leave their children unprotected for longer than they would have been otherwise — potentially exposing them to diseases like measles, even if their parents are planning on eventually giving them the MMR shot.
